page.title: 11R. AIRE & BROTHERTON MARSH
page.content: When the River Aire gets to Ferrybridge it starts to straighten, because it goes through a gap in the {Magnesian limestone}hills. When it gets beyond Knottingley it starts to{meander}for miles and miles. In the River Aire believe it or not there are some{fish.}There are perch, stickleback and roach. All the traffic on the river turns into the canal at Ferrybridge because of the weir at Kings Mills.After Knottingley there is marsh on both sides of the river with barley and wheat fields. Many dykes drain water from the marshland.For farmers {mining subsidence}means drainage is a constant battle.Beyond the tar works is a wetland{bird {sanctuary}at Willow Garths with gold & green finches,blackbird,blue and great tits, kestrel,woodpigeon,and barn owl to be seen.
